The search results provide comprehensive information about how scientific influences, mass production concepts, and behaviorism shaped Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World." Here's what I found:

## Scientific Influences on Brave New World

Scientific advancements also influenced Huxley, especially the work of Ivan Pavlov on conditioned responses and John B. Watson's behaviorism. These discoveries challenged traditional views of human autonomy, suggesting that behavior could be manipulated through stimuli, an idea explored extensively in Brave New World.

### Behaviorism - Pavlov and Watson

Scientist Ivan Pavlov conducts behavioral experiments, demonstrating that animals can develop a conditioned response. John B. Watson establishes the behaviorist school of thought, asserting that human behavior can be reduced to a series of stimuli and responses, which can be manipulated by the experimenter.(no content)The conditioning technique used to instill a dislike for flowers and books in infants is modeled after the research of Ivan Pavlov, a Russian scientist. Pavlov demonstrated that dogs could be trained to salivate at the ringing of a bell if the sound was consistently visually associated with food.

The novel implements these theories through "Neo-Pavlovian Conditioning" - Huxley's term for the dystopian form of infant training. The term derives from the classical conditioning system named for the Russian physiologist Ivan Petrovich Pavlov (1849-1931).

### Henry Ford and Mass Production

Henry Ford was revolutionizing industry with the introduction of the Model T and the electric conveyor belt assembly line in 1914. His factory in Highland Park, Michigan, could produce a car in just ninety-three minutes, capturing a significant share of the automobile market.(no content)The World State is built upon the principles of Henry Ford's assembly line: mass production, homogeneity, predictability, and consumption of disposable consumer goods.

### Ford as a Religious Figure

Henry Ford, who has become a messianic figure to the World State. "Our Ford" is used in place of "Our Lord", as a credit to popularising the use of the assembly line.(no content)The World State calendar numbers years in the "AF" era—"After Ford"—with the calendar beginning in AD 1908, the year in which Ford's first Model T rolled off his assembly line.

### Assembly Line Applied to Human Production

The hatchery is the core of Huxley's sarcastic extrapolation of the principles of American automobile pioneer Henry Ford's assembly-line production system and Frederick Winslow Taylor's theories of applying scientific management to the organization of entire societies.(no content)Ford is the founder of the "assembly line", which is the starting point of mass production. Referring to this fact there is an analogy to the production of human beings in Huxley´s novel. Henry Ford established the breakthrough of industrial production; cars could be produced in great amounts. In Brave New World human beings can be mulitplied and the identical set of people is created.

The search reveals how Huxley masterfully wove together the scientific theories of Pavlov and Watson with Ford's industrial innovations to create a dystopian society where humans are mass-produced and conditioned like products on an assembly line.
